title: Adnan Syed trial: Jay Wilds witness stories and all the inconsistencies
text:
Jay’s stories are one big tangled web

If you’ve continued to follow the case of Serial season one subject Adnan Syed, then you’ll know all about Jay Wilds.

It was Jay’s testimony that helped to put Adnan in prison with a life sentence for the February 1999 murder of his high school girlfriend, Hae Min Lee.

As the state’s star witness, Jay testified that he helped Adnan bury Hae’s body after allegedly confessing to the murder back in February 1999.

Adnan has always professed his innocence and says Jay isn’t being truthful.

While Jay is yet to be proven wrong in a court of law, there’s no denying his stories have been incredibly inconsistent over the years.

Basically, his accounts of what happened that day have changed drastically several times.

Jay Wilds’ first police interview

Adnan remains in jail and maintains his innocence (Picture: Barbara Haddock Taylor/The Baltimore Sun via AP, File)

Adnan and Jay have never claimed to be best friends but more like ‘acquaintances’ – in the sense that Jay would sell Adnan marijuana and they’d hang out from time to time.

Advertisement

Advertisement

But they knew each other well enough for Adnan to willingly give Jay his brand new mobile phone on the day of Hae’s murder.

That’s probably the most that Adnan and Jay agree on.

Thanks to painstaking research by the Undisclosed podcast team, led by Adnan’s family friend Rabia Chaudry, there’s evidence to suggest Jay may have been interviewed by the police off the record.

But in his first recorded interview with the Baltimore police, Jay told police that Adnan had shown him Hae’s body in the parking lot of a Best Buy store where he’s said to have killed her.

He allegedly then helped Adnan bury Hae’s body in Leakin Park at around 7pm that evening.

However during the police interview, Jay often seemed to be confused with the details of the story.

As covered in Undisclosed, the interview audio reveals that at these points, there would be a knock or tap on the table and Jay would suddenly remember the details.

Jay Wilds’ second and third police interviews

During the next two on-record interviews with police, Jay changed key details in his account of the day of the murder.

Advertisement

Advertisement

In one chat with the police, he told them Adnan showed him Hae’s body in the boot of his car on Edmonson Avenue – not Best Buy.

Another time, he claimed that Adnan had actually killed Hae at Patapsco State Park.

In an episode of her Serial podcast, host Sarah Keonig said the ‘spine’ of Jay’s story has never really changed.

According to Koenig, a prosecutor said at the trial: ‘He tells police a consistent story about the defendant, he tells consistently the defendant’s involvement, the defendant’s actions on that day. He has never wavered on that point.’

The state prosecutor was referring to Jay’s account that Adnan strangled Hae to death and showed him the body which he helped bury.

Jay Wilds’ interview with The Intercept

With Adnan serving a life prison sentence, Jay was able to continue living a quiet life under the radar.

That was until Serial garnered worldwide attention and thrust the spotlight onto him – and the holes in his various versions of events.

The Case Against Adnan Syed is available on Sky Crime now

But rather than continue to maintain a wall of silence, Jay made the unprecedented move of sitting down for an interview with The Intercept.

He refused to speak to Koenig for the podcast, so this was a shocking development in the case.

However, it only exposed the inconsistencies of Jay’s stories further and cast even more doubt on Adnan’s guilt.

‘I wasn’t openly willing to cooperate with the police. It wasn’t until they made it clear they weren’t interested in my ‘procurement’ of pot that I began to open up any,’ Jay told Natasha Vargas-Cooper.

Advertisement

So how did Jay’s story change again?

In this 2014 interview, Jay tells the publication that Adnan actually showed him Hae’s body outside his grandmother’s house.

According to Jay, he didn’t tell this version before as he didn’t want to involve his grandmother.

‘I know it didn’t happen anywhere other than my grandmother’s house. I remember the highway traffic to my right, and I remember standing there on the curb. I remember Adnan standing next to me,’ Jay said.

Hae Min Lee was killed in February 1999 (Picture: Woodlawn High School)

As for the time of the burial, Jay now says it was closer to midnight than 7pm.

It’s not just the murder details of which Jay is inconsistent – he tells the publication that he ‘can’t remember ever going to any kinds of functions or endeavours’ with Adnan.

But there is photographic evidence of them together at a party two days after Hae’s went missing.

In Sky Crime’s The Case Against Adnan Syed, Rabia Chaudry challenged Jay’s description of seeing Hae’s body in the car boot, as it wouldn’t have been consistent with the lividity evidence.

‘Hae’s lividity was symmetrical and fully frontal [suggesting she was] lying flat on her face somewhere before she was moved to Leakin Park,’ Chaudry explains.

Advertisement

Jay has not spoken publicly about the case since, although his ex-girlfriend was seen having a phone conversation with him in the last episode of The Case Against Adnan Syed.

Undisclosed podcast co-host Collin Miller recently told Metro.co.uk that if Adnan’s current appeal is unsuccessful, his legal team will look at ways of trying to contact Jay to iron out his story once again.

The Case Against Adnan Syed is available to watch on Sky Crime now.
